The knowledge of truth is the false knowledge and views of the truth of suffering.
How does one know and see?

Suffering is false and unreal, when attained it is suffering, it exists due to inversion. If the bodhisattva knows suffering is unborn and unarisen, this is called knowing and seeing the truth of suffering.
How does one cut off the accumulation?
All dharmas are cut off according to the accumulation.
What is the accumulation?
Because the accumulation is equal, the cutting off is also like this.
Because it comes from nowhere, it accumulates; because it goes nowhere, it ceases. This is called the nature of all dharmas.
In this, there is no real dharma that arises and then ceases. It accumulates due to the influence of craving. If one cuts off the influence of craving, this is called the cessation of accumulation.
What is the truth of the cessation of suffering?
The ultimate cessation of the accumulation of suffering is because there is no dharma that can be destroyed. This is called the cessation of suffering.
All conditioned phenomena cease in this way. In this, there is neither arising nor cessation. This is called the truth of cessation.
What is the truth of the path?

Following any path, one does not attain any dharma, whether wholesome or unwholesome, whether contaminated or uncontaminated, whether conditioned or unconditioned. This is called the truth of the path.
This path is impartial because it does not discriminate any dharma;ğŸ”½this path is tranquil because it is free from the heat of all bonds;

If a bodhisattva knows the four truths by means of such a gateway, this is called the wisdom of the truths.

Moreover, King of Freedom!

If one can know the minds of all sentient beings with a single mind, and know the nature of all minds with the nature of a single mind, yet not engage in dualistic practices regarding the knowledge of the mind, this is called mastery of knowledge.
Moreover, there is mastery of knowledge, knowing and seeing the past without obstruction, yet the mind does not reach the past;
knowing and seeing the future without obstruction, yet the mind does not reach the future;

Moreover, there is mastery of knowledge, knowing the complete cessation of all conditioned phenomena, yet not exhausting wholesome roots;

Moreover, not relying on others, one knows the ultimate cessation of all phenomena, and with this power of knowledge, one does not cease oneself but teaches and transforms sentient beings. This is called mastery of knowledge.

I am a donor, I am one who upholds precepts, I am one who practices patience, I am one who practices diligence, I am one who practices concentration, I am one who practices wisdom, all of these are mental activities;

What is accomplishing sentient beings?

What is upholding the true Dharma?
If one does not uphold any dharmas, this is called upholding the true Dharma.

If one receives wholesome or unwholesome dharmas, it is not receiving and upholding the true Dharma;
If one receives blameworthy or blameless, contaminated or uncontaminated, conditioned or unconditioned, worldly or supramundane dharmas, it is not receiving and upholding the true Dharma;
If one receives the characteristics of giving, it is not receiving and upholding the true Dharma;
If one receives morality, patience, vigor, concentration, and wisdom, it is not receiving and upholding the true Dharma.

What is the unobstructed knowledge of dharmas?
Bodhisattvas rely on the Dharma and do not rely on what is not the Dharma.

Why is it so?
